item.title: When the Dragons are Upon Us
item.description:
"Fairy tales are more than true: not because they tell us that dragons exist, but because they tell us that dragons can be beaten." Neil Gaiman

There are many dragons when it comes to dental health. There is gum disease, there is tooth decay, there is oral cancer, there is malocclusion, there are abscesses, tumors, fractured teeth, missing teeth, and the list goes on and on. A lot of dentists don't think of themselves as dragon killers. But we are. That is the challenge, and it has to be admitted, the fun of dentistry. We spend our days trying to help our patients slay their dental dragons.

The problem we frequently face, though, is many people don't believe in dragons. Or, what may be worse, they don't realize that dragons are chewing on them until it is too late.

That is why dentistry has historically led the field in medicine when it comes to prevention and education. It's not just that dragons can be beaten. It's that with a little prevention they usually can be kept out of the country to begin with. And if one does slip in, they can be beaten fairly easily if caught early enough.

So we at Inge Dental encourage all our patients to come in twice a year for routine cleanings, exams, fluoride treatments and x-rays if they are needed. To slay your dragons, contact us to make an appointment for a cleaning and exam today!

Dragons can be beaten.

Tags: 
dental health
gum disease
tooth decay
oral cancer
cleanings
fluoride treatments

item.title: Dragons Can Be Beaten
item.description:
“Fairy tales are more than true: not because they tell us that dragons exist, but because they tell us that dragons can be beaten.” Neil Gaiman

Tags: 
dental health
item.dc:creator: Dr. Inge

item.title: Time
item.description:
For some reason, there has been a lot of talk about time lately on TV and in the press. You’ll even see an article or two in the scientific journals. It’s a huge topic, from a lot of different perspectives, but there was one take regarding time that is particularly interesting. Time is cumulative in many things we do. Don’t feel bad if you don’t have a clue as to what that means. We didn’t either. The idea is that there are a huge number of seemingly little things that can really affect our lives if done repeatedly over time. But they have to be done repeatedly. That is the point. The effects, for good or bad, accumulate and can’t be un-done very easily.

An example:

If a person skips a week of exercising, no big deal. However, if a person doesn’t exercise over a period of 52 weeks (a year for those who don’t like math), he/she will not look or feel very well, and could be extremely unhealthy. If that same person had exercised three days a week over the period of a year, their looks and the way they feel would be exponentially better. Now here is the kicker. The effects of a year of sedentary living cannot be turned around by one week of exercise, no matter how tough the work out. The person got to where he or she is over an expanse of time, and that person can only reverse the process over a period of time. There are no short cuts. The sad thing about it all is that sometimes the consequences of cumulative behavior are irreversible or extremely difficult to correct. In our example with exercise, a sedentary lifestyle can lead to heart disease, diabetes, obesity, poor job performance, and a shorter life span. This whole thing about the cumulative effects of time applies to relationships, diet, studying—the list goes on and on. It is important.

What does this have to do with dentistry? A lot. Gum disease, tooth decay, abscesses, and tooth loss don’t come as a result of forgetting to brush your teeth one night. But not brushing your teeth night after night? A little thing like not brushing your teeth at night, done over and over, can lead to all of these problems. They are the cumulative effects of doing a small thing wrong over and over. And repairing these things cannot be done in a week. Now you are talking about infections, root canals, crowns, implants, or extractions. Expensive and possibly painful stuff. And it all could have to been avoided with a little tooth brush.

So don’t forget the small stuff. Daily brushing and flossing combined with two professional cleanings and exams a year can keep your teeth in the dental Promised Land. It will save you big bucks and a lot of TIME.

Tags: 
dental health
brushing
flossing
item.dc:creator: Dr. Inge

item.title: Satan and Good Health
item.description:
In his book, Tide Rising, Bruce Theileman tells an interesting story. Here is a VERY modified version:

One day Satan gathered his demons and asked for a volunteer to come up with a message to deliver that would ruin men's souls.

The first volunteer said, "I will tell them there is no heaven." Satan replied, "They will not believe you, for there is a bit of heaven in every human heart. You may not go."

The second volunteer said, "I will tell them there is no hell." Satan replied, "They will not believe you, for there is an inner voice in every human heart that says evil will be punished."

Then from the darkest pit of hell came a volunteer who said, "Send me and I will tell them 'there is no hurry".

Satan said, "Go".

A bit theological, perhaps, but this story pertains a lot to human health. Procrastination, especially in matters of health, lies deep within the human heart. "I'll start watching what I eat tomorrow." "I will start exercising tomorrow."

Good dental care is no exception. People continue to lose teeth do to—procrastination. Procrastination in brushing and flossing. Procrastination in that all important six month checkup. Procrastination in getting that tooth colored filling or crown done that was diagnosed months ago. The longer things go untreated, the worse things are when treatment is absolutely necessary and procrastination is impossible.

That being said, however, dentistry is on the cutting edge of making procrastination difficult. A terrific smile and fresh breath is the model in a huge number of commercials. And the best way to get that, obviously, is routine brushing and flossing and routine dental checkups every six months. Cosmetic dentistry and bleaching can give you that TV commercial smile. In this technological age, we make things easy. We offer many ways to make appointments online. We can send out multiple reminders of appointments by email or text.

So don't believe it the next time the demon says there is no hurry. The best time to take care of your teeth is now.

Tags: 
procrastination
dental health
brushing
flossing
checkup
item.dc:creator: Dr. Inge
